evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is available in the hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim dataset.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and no coordination failure, or if the dataset did not include such communication breakdown details.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 directly describe communication and coordination among crew and support the availability of communication/coordination breakdown data in the dataset. H8 specifically highlights lack of warning signals, indicating coordination failure.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim data.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 directly describe communication and coordination issues among crew during pushback, including ineffective signaling and lack of warnings, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown aligning with key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in extent to which environment or markings contributed versus communication breakdown

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim is resistant to defeaters based on the available evidence.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies communication breakdown rather than mechanical failure.
The tug instructor's statement about signaling reflects the actual communication environment.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication signals were given and ignored, or if hardware faults were identified that better explain the incident, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 show active communication and coordination attempts among crew and operators, but also highlight limitations in signaling and lack of warnings, supporting that the communication breakdown is resistant to defeaters and not due to mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential missing evidence on other communication attempts or hardware status; ambiguity in interpreting the sufficiency of visual signals.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim phase.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings are assumed to be visible and adequate as per H7, though not explicitly confirmed in the evidence for this incident.
The procedural deviation is inferred from the continuation beyond the TRP and lack of warnings, assuming no other external factors caused the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were inadequate or not visible, or if environmental factors prevented compliance, this would change the assessment.
If mechanical control failures or communication breakdowns were documented as causes, this would reduce support for procedural deviation.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 documents the procedural deviation with the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier. H8 and H9 support that the deviation was due to procedural issues rather than environmental factors, favoring the procedural deviation hypothesis over environment deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on environmental marking adequacy or mechanical failure is provided, so some uncertainty remains.
